docs.abstract: Shares of airlines plunged and industrial, financial and energy stocks also fell sharply. Asian markets followed Wall Street lower.
docs.snippet: Shares of airlines plunged and industrial, financial and energy stocks also fell sharply. Asian markets followed Wall Street lower.
docs.lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Coverage of Friday’s markets can be found here.

headline.main: Stocks Plunge Again on Coronavirus Fears
headline.print_headline: Markets Plunge Again on Virus Worries

docs.abstract: Gary Jones, the United Auto Workers leader until last fall, is accused of embezzlement. A prosecutor spoke of a previous U.S. takeover of a union as a model.
docs.snippet: Gary Jones, the United Auto Workers leader until last fall, is accused of embezzlement. A prosecutor spoke of a previous U.S. takeover of a union as a model.
docs.lead_paragraph: For five years, federal investigators have pieced together a broad pattern of corruption within the United Automobile Workers. They documented the diversion of dues for high living by union officials and found a conspiracy that may have compromised dealings with a leading automaker.

headline.main: U.A.W. Corruption Case Widens as Former Chief Is Charged
headline.print_headline: Former Chief  Now Charged In U.A.W. Case

byline.original: By Noam Scheiber and Neal E. Boudette

docs.abstract: Lydia Polgreen, who has been the editor in chief at the news website since 2016, is stepping down for a role at Gimlet Media.
docs.snippet: Lydia Polgreen, who has been the editor in chief at the news website since 2016, is stepping down for a role at Gimlet Media.
docs.lead_paragraph: In another shake-up of the digital news landscape, HuffPost’s editor in chief, Lydia Polgreen, announced Friday that she was departing the website for a sector that many in media see as more of a growth area: podcasting.

headline.main: HuffPost’s Top Editor Leaves for a Podcasting Company

docs.abstract: As the coronavirus spreads around the world, companies are seeking alternatives to making goods in China, while right-wing political parties fulminate against open borders.
docs.snippet: As the coronavirus spreads around the world, companies are seeking alternatives to making goods in China, while right-wing political parties fulminate against open borders.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Well before a deadly virus began spreading across multiple borders, a world defined by deepening interconnection appeared to be reassessing the merits of globalization.

headline.main: A Global Outbreak Is Fueling the Backlash to Globalization
headline.print_headline: Virus Adds To Backlash To a World Intertwined

docs.abstract: In a candid interview, David Calhoun largely laid the blame for the company’s 737 Max crisis on his predecessor.
docs.snippet: In a candid interview, David Calhoun largely laid the blame for the company’s 737 Max crisis on his predecessor.
docs.lead_paragraph: FLORISSANT, Mo. — In his eight weeks on the job, Boeing’s chief executive, David L. Calhoun, has come to one overriding conclusion: Things inside the aerospace giant were even worse than he had thought.

headline.main: ‘It’s More Than I Imagined’: Boeing’s New C.E.O. Confronts Its Challenges
headline.print_headline: Boeing’s Problems  Are a Lot Bigger Than He Feared

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

byline.original: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

docs.abstract: Regulators report thousands of complaints about the calls. Here are some tips on protecting yourself, and your money.
docs.snippet: Regulators report thousands of complaints about the calls. Here are some tips on protecting yourself, and your money.
docs.lead_paragraph: You’ve probably received one: A recorded call warns of a problem with your Social Security number. To fix it and avoid legal action, you’re told, you must call back immediately — and pay up.

headline.main: How Not to Become a Victim of Social Security Fraud Calls
headline.print_headline: How Not to Become a Victim of Social Security Fraud Calls

docs.abstract: The latest Apple and Google models have software that automatically enhances your photos, but you can also take control to get your perfect shot.
docs.snippet: The latest Apple and Google models have software that automatically enhances your photos, but you can also take control to get your perfect shot.
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s getting harder to take a truly bad photo on a good smartphone. Thanks to better lenses, robust processors and integrated computational photography software to process images under the hood, even scenes in low-light, no-flash situations that used to be hopelessly murky can now turn out nicely.

headline.main: Get the Most Out of Your Fancy Smartphone Camera
headline.print_headline: The Quest for That Perfect Shot

docs.abstract: Nestlé wants to draw more spring water from a northern Florida site owned by a local family — but environmentalists are pushing back.
docs.snippet: Nestlé wants to draw more spring water from a northern Florida site owned by a local family — but environmentalists are pushing back.
docs.lead_paragraph: HIGH SPRINGS, Fla. — One by one, the mermaids dived into the water.

headline.main: Where Mermaids Play, a Nasty Water Fight
headline.print_headline: In Florida, Troubled Waters As Nestlé Pushes for More

docs.abstract: The spreading coronavirus could hamper global growth. Investors are hoping central banks will step in to offset the damage.
docs.snippet: The spreading coronavirus could hamper global growth. Investors are hoping central banks will step in to offset the damage.
docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks surged in the final minutes of trading on Monday, snapping back from one of the worst weeks for global markets since the 2008 financial crisis as investors seized on promises that the world’s governments would step in to help if the global economy was slammed by the outbreak of the coronavirus.

headline.main: Stocks Surge as Central Banks Vow to Act on Coronavirus

docs.abstract: The stock market had its worst week since 2008, signaling that one of the longest expansions in history could be ending. Policymakers said they were ready to act.
docs.snippet: The stock market had its worst week since 2008, signaling that one of the longest expansions in history could be ending. Policymakers said they were ready to act.
docs.lead_paragraph: Investors, fearing that the spread of the coronavirus is tipping the global economy into a recession, handed the stock market its largest weekly loss since the 2008 financial crisis on Friday amid worries that one of the longest economic expansions in history may be coming to an end.

headline.main: Coronavirus Fears Reverberate Across Global Economy
headline.print_headline: Wall St. Suffers its Worst Week Since 2008 as Virus Angst Grows
